content:
No, the standard deviation of the combined measurements does not directly give you the range of variation of the amount of alcohol in each sample of liquid. Instead, it gives you an indication of the amount of variation in the combined measurements of the amount of liquid and the amount of alcohol in the liquid.

To estimate the range of variation of the amount of alcohol in each sample of liquid, you can use the following approach:

1. Calculate the mean of the sample measurements for the amount of liquid:
Mean liquid = (95+97+101+102+104)/5 = 99.8 grams
2. Calculate the mean of the sample measurements for the amount of alcohol:
Mean alcohol = (26+28+31+33)/4 = 29 grams
3. For each sample, calculate the amount of alcohol in grams per 100 grams of liquid:
Sample 1: alcohol content = 26/95 x 100 = 27.37 grams/100 grams
Sample 2: alcohol content = 28/97 x 100 = 28.87 grams/100 grams
Sample 3: alcohol content = 31/101 x 100 = 30.69 grams/100 grams
Sample 4: alcohol content = 33/102 x 100 = 32.35 grams/100 grams
Sample 5: alcohol content = 33/104 x 100 = 31.73 grams/100 grams
4. Calculate the range of variation of the amount of alcohol in each sample by finding the minimum and maximum values of the alcohol content among the samples:
Minimum alcohol content = 27.37 grams/100 grams
Maximum alcohol content = 32.35 grams/100 grams

Therefore, the amount of alcohol in each sample of liquid is expected to vary from approximately 27.37 grams/100 grams to 32.35 grams/100 grams. This range reflects the variability of the actual amount of alcohol in each sample, taking into account the variability in the measurements of the amount of liquid and the amount of alcohol in the liquid.
